Convergence and Accuracy Trade-Offs in Federated Learning and Meta-Learning


 


Zachary Charles                        Jakub Konečný

Google Research                        Google Research

Abstract

We study a family of algorithms, which we refer to as local update methods, generalizing many federated and meta-learning algorithms. We prove that for quadratic models, local update methods are equivalent to first-order optimization on a surrogate loss we exactly characterize. Moreover, fundamental algorithmic choices (such as learning rates) explicitly govern a trade-off between the condition number of the surrogate loss and its alignment with the true loss. We derive novel convergence rates showcasing these trade-offs and highlight their importance in communication-limited settings. Using these insights, we are able to compare local update methods based on their convergence/accuracy trade-off, not just their convergence to critical points of the empirical loss. Our results shed new light on a broad range of phenomena, including the efficacy of server momentum in federated learning and the impact of proximal client updates.

1 Introduction

Federated learning (McMahan et al., 2017) is a distributed framework for learning models without directly sharing data. In this framework, clients perform local updates (typically using first-order optimization) on their own data. In the popular FedAvg algorithm (McMahan et al., 2017), the client models are then averaged at a central server. Since the proposal of FedAvg, many new federated optimization algorithms have been developed (Li et al., 2020a; Reddi et al., 2020; Hsu et al., 2019; Xie et al., 2019; Basu et al., 2019; Li et al., 2020b; Karimireddy et al., 2019). These methods typically employ multiple local client epochs in order to improve communication-efficiency. We defer to Kairouz et al. (2019) and Li et al. (2019) for more detailed summaries of federated learning.

Local updates have also been used extensively in meta-learning. The celebrated MAML algorithm (Finn et al., 2017) employs multiple local model updates on a set of tasks in order to learn a model that quickly adapt to new tasks. MAML has inspired a number of model-agnostic meta-learning methods that also employ first-order local updates (Balcan et al., 2019; Fallah et al., 2020a; Nichol et al., 2018; Zhou et al., 2019). There are strong connections between federated learning and meta-learning, despite differences in practical concerns. Formal connections between the two were shown by Khodak et al. (2019) and have since been explored in many other works (Jiang et al., 2019; Fallah et al., 2020b).

We refer to methods that utilize multiple local updates across clients (or in the language of meta-learning, tasks) as local update methods (see Section 2.1 for a formal characterization). In practice, local update methods frequently outperform “centralized” methods such as SGD (McMahan et al., 2017; Finn et al., 2017; Hard et al., 2018; Yang et al., 2018; Hard et al., 2020). However, the empirical benefits of local update methods are not fully explained by existing theoretical analyses. For example, Woodworth et al. (2020) show that FedAvg often obtains convergence rates comparable to or worse than those of mini-batch SGD.

We focus on two difficulties that arise when analyzing local update methods. First, analyses must account for client drift (Karimireddy et al., 2019). As clients perform local updates on heterogeneous datasets, their local models drift apart. This hinders convergence to globally optimal models, and makes theoretical analyses more challenging. Similar phenomena were examined by Li et al. (2020a); Malinovsky et al. (2020); Pathak and Wainwright (2020) and Fallah et al. (2020b), who show that various local update methods do not converge to critical points of the empirical loss.

Second, local update methods are difficult to compare. Analyses of different methods may use different hyperparameters regimes, or make different assumptions. Even comparing seemingly similar methods can require significant theoretical insight (Karimireddy et al., 2019; Fallah et al., 2020b). Moreover, comparisons can be made in fundamentally different ways. One may wish to maximize the final accuracy, or minimize the number of communication rounds needed to attain a given accuracy. Thus, it is not even clear how local update methods should be compared.

Contributions

In this work, we invert the conventional narrative that issues such as client drift harm convergence. Instead, we view such phenomena as improving convergence, but to sub-optimal points.

More generally, we show that local update methods face a fundamental trade-off between convergence and accuracy that is explicitly governed by algorithmic hyperparameters. Perceived failures of methods such as FedAvg actually correspond to operating points prioritizing convergence over accuracy. We use this trade-off to develop a novel framework for comparing local update methods. We compare methods based on their entire convergence-accuracy trade-off, not just their convergence to optimal points. In more detail:

  1. 1.

    We show that for quadratic models, local update methods are equivalent to optimizing a single surrogate loss function. The condition number of the surrogate is controlled by algorithmic choices. Popular local update methods, including FedAvg and MAML, reduce the surrogate’s condition number, but increase the discrepancy between the empirical and surrogate losses. Our results also encompass proximal local update methods (Li et al., 2020a; Zhou et al., 2019).

  2. 2.

    We derive novel convergence rates that showcasing this trade-off between convergence and accuracy. Our bounds demonstrate the benefit of local update methods over methods such as mini-batch SGD in communication-limited settings.

  3. 3.

    We use this theory to develop a framework for comparing local update methods through a novel Pareto frontier, which compares convergence-accuracy trade-offs of classes of algorithms. We use this to derive novel comparisons of many popular local update methods.

  4. 4.

    We use this technique to shed light on a broad range of phenomena, including the benefit of server momentum, the effect of proximal local updates, and differences between the dynamics of FedAvg and MAML.

  5. 5.

    While our theoretical results are restricted to quadratic models, we show that such convergence-accuracy trade-offs occur empirically in non-convex settings. We also validate our theoretical observations regarding server momentum and proximal updates on a non-convex task.

We view our work as a step towards holistic understandings of local update methods. Using the aforementioned Pareto frontiers, we highlight a number of new phenomena and open problems. One particularly intriguing observation is that the convergence-accuracy trade-off for FedAvg with heavy-ball server momentum appears to be completely symmetric. For more details, see Section 5. Our proof techniques may be of independent interest. We derive a novel analog of the Bhatia-Davis inequality (Bhatia and Davis, 2000) for mean absolute deviations, and use this to understand the accuracy of local update methods.

Notation

We let ∥⋅∥delimited-∥∥⋅\left\lVert\cdot\right\rVert denote the ℓ2subscriptℓ2\ell_{2} norm for vectors and the spectral norm for matrices. For a symmetric positive semi-definite matrix A𝐴A, we let A1/2superscript𝐴12A^{1/2} denote its matrix square root. We let ⪯precedes-or-equals\preceq be the Loewner order on positive semi-definite matrices. For a real symmetric matrix A𝐴A, we let λmax​(A)subscript𝜆𝐴\lambda_{\max}(A), λmin​(A)subscript𝜆𝐴\lambda_{\min}(A) denote its largest and smallest eigenvalues, and let cond(A)cond𝐴\operatorname*{cond}(A) denote their ratio. Accuracy and Meta-Learning

We study the accuracy of local update methods on the training population. However, meta-learning algorithms are designed to learn a model that adapts well to new tasks; The empirical loss is not necessarily indicative of the “post-adaptation” accuracy of such methods (Finn et al., 2017). Despite this our focus still yields novel insights into qualitative differences between the training dynamics of federated learning and meta-learning methods. Perhaps surprisingly, we show that in certain hyperparameter regions, these methods exhibit identical trade-offs between convergence and pre-adaptation accuracy (see Figures 4 and 5). While we believe our results can be adapted to post-adaptation accuracy via techniques developed by Fallah et al. (2020a), we leave the analysis to future work.

2.1 Local Update Methods

We consider a class of algorithms we refer to as local update methods. In these methods, at each round t𝑡t the server samples a set Itsubscript𝐼𝑡I_{t} of M𝑀M clients (in the language of meta-learning, tasks) from 𝒫𝒫\mathcal{P}, and broadcasts its model xtsubscript𝑥𝑡x_{t} to all clients in Itsubscript𝐼𝑡I_{t}. Each client i∈It𝑖subscript𝐼𝑡i\in I_{t} optimizes its loss function fisubscript𝑓𝑖f_{i} (starting at xtsubscript𝑥𝑡x_{t}) by applying K𝐾K iterations of mini-batch SGD with batch size B𝐵B and client learning rate γ𝛾\gamma. As proposed by Li et al. (2020a) and Zhou et al. (2019), clients also add ℓ2subscriptℓ2\ell_{2} regularization with parameter α≥0𝛼0\alpha\geq 0 towards the broadcast model xtsubscript𝑥𝑡x_{t}.

The client sends a linear combination of the gradients it computes to the server. The coefficients of the linear combination are given by Θ=(θ1,θ2,…,θk,…)Θsubscript𝜃1subscript𝜃2…subscript𝜃𝑘…\Theta=(\theta_{1},\theta_{2},\dots,\theta_{k},\dots) for θi∈ℝ≥0subscript𝜃𝑖subscriptℝabsent0\theta_{i}\in\mathbb{R}_{\geq 0}, where ΘΘ\Theta has finite and non-zero support. For such ΘΘ\Theta, we define

K​(Θ):=max⁡{k​|θk>​0},w​(Θ)=∑k=1K​(Θ)θk.formulae-sequenceassign𝐾Θ𝑘ketsubscript𝜃𝑘0𝑤Θsuperscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾Θsubscript𝜃𝑘K(\Theta):=\max\{k~{}|~{}\theta_{k}>0\},~{}~{}w(\Theta)=\sum_{k=1}^{K(\Theta)}\theta_{k}. (4)

After receiving all client updates, the server treats their average qtsubscript𝑞𝑡q_{t} as an estimate of the gradient of the loss function f𝑓f, and applies qtsubscript𝑞𝑡q_{t} to a first-order optimization algorithm ServerOpt. For example, the server could perform a gradient descent step using the “pseudo-gradient” qtsubscript𝑞𝑡q_{t}. We refer to this process (parameterized by α,γ,Θ𝛼𝛾Θ\alpha,\gamma,\Theta and ServerOpt) as LocalUpdate and give pseudo-code in Algorithms 1 and 2.

LocalUpdate recovers many well-known algorithms for various choices ΘΘ\Theta. For convenience, define

ΘK:=(0,…,0⏟K-1 times,1),Θ1:K:=(1,…,1⏟K times).formulae-sequenceassignsubscriptΘ𝐾subscript⏟0…0K-1 times1assignsubscriptΘ:1𝐾subscript⏟1…1K times\Theta_{K}:=(\underbrace{0,\dots,0}_{\text{K-1 times}},1),~{}~{}~{}\Theta_{1:K}:=(\underbrace{1,\dots,1}_{\text{K times}}). (5)

Special cases of LocalUpdate when ServerOpt is gradient descent are given in Table 1. For details on the relation between FedAvg and LocalUpdate, see Appendix A. By changing ServerOpt, we can recover methods such as FedAvgM (Hsu et al., 2019) (server gradient descent with momentum), and FedAdam (Reddi et al., 2020) (server Adam (Kingma and Ba, 2014)).

3 Local Update Methods as First-Order Methods

LocalUpdate can vary drastically from first-order optimization methods on the empirical loss. Despite this, we will show that Algorithm 2 is equivalent in expectation to ServerOpt applied to a single surrogate loss. This surrogate loss is determined by the inputs α,γ𝛼𝛾\alpha,\gamma and ΘΘ\Theta to Algorithm 2. For each client i∈ℐ𝑖ℐi\in\mathcal{I}, we define its distortion matrix Qi​(α,γ,Θ)subscript𝑄𝑖𝛼𝛾ΘQ_{i}(\alpha,\gamma,\Theta) as

Qi​(α,γ,Θ):=∑k=1K​(Θ)θk​(I−γ​(Ai+α​I))k−1.assignsubscript𝑄𝑖𝛼𝛾Θsuperscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾Θsubscript𝜃𝑘superscript𝐼𝛾subscript𝐴𝑖𝛼𝐼𝑘1Q_{i}(\alpha,\gamma,\Theta):=\sum_{k=1}^{K(\Theta)}\theta_{k}(I-\gamma(A_{i}+\alpha I))^{k-1}. (6)

We define the surrogate loss function of client i𝑖i as

f~i​(x,α,γ,Θ):=12​‖(Qi​(α,γ,Θ)​Ai)1/2​(x−ci)‖2assignsubscript~𝑓𝑖𝑥𝛼𝛾Θ12superscriptnormsuperscriptsubscript𝑄𝑖𝛼𝛾Θsubscript𝐴𝑖12𝑥subscript𝑐𝑖2\tilde{f}_{i}(x,\alpha,\gamma,\Theta):=\frac{1}{2}\|(Q_{i}(\alpha,\gamma,\Theta)A_{i})^{1/2}(x-c_{i})\|^{2} (7)

and the overall surrogate loss function as

f~​(x,α,γ,Θ):=𝔼i∼𝒫[f~i​(x,α,γ,Θ)].assign~𝑓𝑥𝛼𝛾Θsubscript𝔼similar-to𝑖𝒫subscript~𝑓𝑖𝑥𝛼𝛾Θ\tilde{f}(x,\alpha,\gamma,\Theta):=\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{i\sim\mathcal{P}}[\tilde{f}_{i}(x,\alpha,\gamma,\Theta)]. (8)

When Θ=Θ1ΘsubscriptΘ1\Theta=\Theta_{1}, Qi​(α,γ,Θ)=Isubscript𝑄𝑖𝛼𝛾Θ𝐼Q_{i}(\alpha,\gamma,\Theta)=I, in which case there is no distortion. In general, Qi​(α,γ,Θ)subscript𝑄𝑖𝛼𝛾ΘQ_{i}(\alpha,\gamma,\Theta) can amplify the heterogeneity of the Aisubscript𝐴𝑖A_{i}. We derive the following theorem linking the surrogate losses to Algorithm 2.

Theorem 1.

For all i∈𝒫𝑖𝒫i\in\mathcal{P},

𝔼[ClientUpdate​(i,x,α,γ,Θ)]=∇f~i​(x,α,γ,Θ).𝔼ClientUpdate𝑖𝑥𝛼𝛾Θ∇subscript~𝑓𝑖𝑥𝛼𝛾Θ\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}[\textsc{ClientUpdate}(i,x,\alpha,\gamma,\Theta)]=\nabla\tilde{f}_{i}(x,\alpha,\gamma,\Theta).

For qtsubscript𝑞𝑡q_{t} as in Algorithm 1, Theorem 1 implies 𝔼[qt]=∇f~​(x,α,γ,Θ)𝔼subscript𝑞𝑡∇~𝑓𝑥𝛼𝛾Θ\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}[q_{t}]=\nabla\tilde{f}(x,\alpha,\gamma,\Theta). Thus, one round of LocalUpdate is equivalent in expectation to one step of ServerOpt on the surrogate loss f~​(x,α,γ,Θ)~𝑓𝑥𝛼𝛾Θ\tilde{f}(x,\alpha,\gamma,\Theta). As γ→0→𝛾0\gamma\to 0 or K→1→𝐾1K\to 1, f~​(x,α,γ,Θ)→w​(Θ)​f​(x)→~𝑓𝑥𝛼𝛾Θ𝑤Θ𝑓𝑥\tilde{f}(x,\alpha,\gamma,\Theta)\to w(\Theta)f(x), so as γ𝛾\gamma gets smaller, the “pseudo-gradients” qtsubscript𝑞𝑡q_{t} more closely resemble stochastic gradients of the empirical loss function.

A version of Theorem 1 was shown for α=0,Θ=Θ2formulae-sequence𝛼0ΘsubscriptΘ2\alpha=0,\Theta=\Theta_{2} by Fallah et al. (2020b). We take this a step further and show that in certain settings, MAML is equivalent in expectation to ServerOpt on a surrogate loss.

MAML

MAML with K𝐾K local steps can be viewed as a modification of LocalUpdate. Algorithm 1 remains the same, and in Algorithm 2, each client executes K𝐾K mini-batch SGD steps. However, the client’s message to the server is different. Let XKi​(x)superscriptsubscript𝑋𝐾𝑖𝑥X_{K}^{i}(x) be the function that runs K𝐾K steps of mini-batch SGD, starting from x𝑥x, for fixed mini-batches S1,…,SKsubscript𝑆1…subscript𝑆𝐾S_{1},\dots,S_{K} of size B𝐵B drawn independently from 𝒟isubscript𝒟𝑖\mathcal{D}_{i}. Define

mKi​(x;z)=f​(XKi​(x);z),mKi​(x)=𝔼z∼𝒟i[mKi​(x;z)].formulae-sequencesubscriptsuperscript𝑚𝑖𝐾𝑥𝑧𝑓superscriptsubscript𝑋𝐾𝑖𝑥𝑧superscriptsubscript𝑚𝐾𝑖𝑥subscript𝔼similar-to𝑧subscript𝒟𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝑚𝑖𝐾𝑥𝑧m^{i}_{K}(x;z)=f(X_{K}^{i}(x);z),~{}m_{K}^{i}(x)=\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{z\sim\mathcal{D}_{i}}[m^{i}_{K}(x;z)].

Each client i𝑖i sends a stochastic estimate of ∇mKi​(x)∇superscriptsubscript𝑚𝐾𝑖𝑥\nabla m_{K}^{i}(x) to the server. The rest is identical to LocalUpdate; The server averages the client outputs and uses this as a gradient estimate for ServerOpt. While MAML is not a special case of LocalUpdate, we show that if the clients use gradient descent, MAML is equivalent in expectation to LocalUpdate with Θ=Θ2​K+1ΘsubscriptΘ2𝐾1\Theta=\Theta_{2K+1}.

Theorem 2.

If XKi​(x)superscriptsubscript𝑋𝐾𝑖𝑥X_{K}^{i}(x) is the function that runs K𝐾K steps of gradient descent on 𝒟isubscript𝒟𝑖\mathcal{D}_{i} with learning rate γ𝛾\gamma starting at x𝑥x, then

∇mKi​(x)=∇xf~i​(x,0,γ,Θ2​K+1).∇subscriptsuperscript𝑚𝑖𝐾𝑥subscript∇𝑥subscript~𝑓𝑖𝑥0𝛾subscriptΘ2𝐾1\nabla m^{i}_{K}(x)=\nabla_{x}\tilde{f}_{i}(x,0,\gamma,\Theta_{2K+1}).

An analogous result holds if the clients perform proximal updates (α>0𝛼0\alpha>0 in ClientUpdate). Thus, to understand LocalUpdate and MAML on quadratic models, it suffices to analyze the optimization dynamics of f~​(x,α,γ,Θ)~𝑓𝑥𝛼𝛾Θ\tilde{f}(x,\alpha,\gamma,\Theta). We use this viewpoint to study the convergence and accuracy of these methods.

4 Convergence and Accuracy of Local Update Methods

Comparing (2) and (8), we see that f~​(x,α,γ,Θ)~𝑓𝑥𝛼𝛾Θ\tilde{f}(x,\alpha,\gamma,\Theta) and f​(x)𝑓𝑥f(x) need not share critical points. Special cases of this fact were noted by Malinovsky et al. (2020), Fallah et al. (2020b), and Pathak and Wainwright (2020). We will show that this is not a failure of local update methods. Rather, by altering the loss function being optimized, LocalUpdate can greatly improve convergence, but to a less accurate point. More generally, the choice of α,γ𝛼𝛾\alpha,\gamma and ΘΘ\Theta dictates a trade-off between convergence and accuracy. Intuitively, the larger γ𝛾\gamma and K​(Θ)𝐾ΘK(\Theta) are, the faster LocalUpdate will converge, and the less accurate the resulting model may be.

To show this formally, we restrict to Qi​(α,γ,Θ)≻0succeedssubscript𝑄𝑖𝛼𝛾Θ0Q_{i}(\alpha,\gamma,\Theta)\succ 0, as then f~​(x,γ,Θ)~𝑓𝑥𝛾Θ\tilde{f}(x,\gamma,\Theta) is strongly convex with a unique minimizer. This is ensured by the following.

Lemma 1.

Suppose that γ<(L+α)−1𝛾superscript𝐿𝛼1\gamma<(L+\alpha)^{-1}. Then for all i𝑖i, Qi​(α,γ,Θ)subscript𝑄𝑖𝛼𝛾ΘQ_{i}(\alpha,\gamma,\Theta) is positive definite and f~​(x,α,γ,Θ)~𝑓𝑥𝛼𝛾Θ\tilde{f}(x,\alpha,\gamma,\Theta) is strongly convex.

4.1 Condition Numbers

Under the conditions of Lemma 1, f~i​(x,α,γ,Θ)subscript~𝑓𝑖𝑥𝛼𝛾Θ\tilde{f}_{i}(x,\alpha,\gamma,\Theta) has a well-defined condition number which we bound.

Lemma 2.

Suppose γ<(L+α)−1𝛾superscript𝐿𝛼1\gamma<(L+\alpha)^{-1}. Define

κ​(α,γ,Θ):=𝔼i[λmax(Qi(α,γ,Θ)Ai]𝔼i[λmin(Qi(α,γ,Θ)Ai].\kappa(\alpha,\gamma,\Theta):=\dfrac{\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{i}[\lambda_{\max}(Q_{i}(\alpha,\gamma,\Theta)A_{i}]}{\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{i}[\lambda_{\min}(Q_{i}(\alpha,\gamma,\Theta)A_{i}]}. (9)

Then cond(f~)≤κ​(α,γ,Θ)cond~𝑓𝜅𝛼𝛾Θ\operatorname*{cond}(\tilde{f})\leq\kappa(\alpha,\gamma,\Theta).

We wish to better understand (9) in cases of interest. We first consider Θ=Θ1:KΘsubscriptΘ:1𝐾\Theta=\Theta_{1:K}, as in FedAvg. Define

ϕ​(λ,α,γ,K):=∑k=1K(1−γ​(λ+α))k−1​λ.assignitalic-ϕ𝜆𝛼𝛾𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾superscript1𝛾𝜆𝛼𝑘1𝜆\phi(\lambda,\alpha,\gamma,K):=\sum_{k=1}^{K}(1-\gamma(\lambda+\alpha))^{k-1}\lambda. (10)

We now derive a bound on cond(f~)cond~𝑓\operatorname*{cond}(\tilde{f}) for Θ=Θ1:KΘsubscriptΘ:1𝐾\Theta=\Theta_{1:K}.

Lemma 3.

If γ<(L+α)−1𝛾superscript𝐿𝛼1\gamma<(L+\alpha)^{-1}, f~​(x,α,γ,Θ1:K)~𝑓𝑥𝛼𝛾subscriptΘ:1𝐾\tilde{f}(x,\alpha,\gamma,\Theta_{1:K}) is ϕ​(L,α,γ,K)italic-ϕ𝐿𝛼𝛾𝐾\phi(L,\alpha,\gamma,K)-smooth, ϕ​(μ,α,γ,K)italic-ϕ𝜇𝛼𝛾𝐾\phi(\mu,\alpha,\gamma,K)-strongly convex, and cond(f~)≤κ​(α,γ,ΘK)cond~𝑓𝜅𝛼𝛾subscriptΘ𝐾\operatorname*{cond}(\tilde{f})\leq\kappa(\alpha,\gamma,\Theta_{K}) where

κ​(α,γ,Θ1:K)≤ϕ​(L,α,γ,K)ϕ​(μ,α,γ,K).𝜅𝛼𝛾subscriptΘ:1𝐾italic-ϕ𝐿𝛼𝛾𝐾italic-ϕ𝜇𝛼𝛾𝐾\kappa(\alpha,\gamma,\Theta_{1:K})\leq\dfrac{\phi(L,\alpha,\gamma,K)}{\phi(\mu,\alpha,\gamma,K)}. (11)

When γ=0,α=0formulae-sequence𝛾0𝛼0\gamma=0,\alpha=0, we recover the condition number L/μ𝐿𝜇L/\mu of the empirical loss f𝑓f. We next consider Θ=ΘKΘsubscriptΘ𝐾\Theta=\Theta_{K}, as in MAML-style algorithms. Define

ψ​(λ,α,γ,K):=(1−γ​(λ+α))K−1​λ.assign𝜓𝜆𝛼𝛾𝐾superscript1𝛾𝜆𝛼𝐾1𝜆\psi(\lambda,\alpha,\gamma,K):=(1-\gamma(\lambda+\alpha))^{K-1}\lambda. (12)

We now derive a bound on cond(f~)cond~𝑓\operatorname*{cond}(\tilde{f}) for Θ=ΘKΘsubscriptΘ𝐾\Theta=\Theta_{K}.

Lemma 4.

If γ<(K​L+α)−1𝛾superscript𝐾𝐿𝛼1\gamma<(KL+\alpha)^{-1}, f~​(x,α,γ,ΘK)~𝑓𝑥𝛼𝛾subscriptΘ𝐾\tilde{f}(x,\alpha,\gamma,\Theta_{K}) is ψ​(L,α,γ,K)𝜓𝐿𝛼𝛾𝐾\psi(L,\alpha,\gamma,K)-smooth, ψ​(μ,α,γ,K)𝜓𝜇𝛼𝛾𝐾\psi(\mu,\alpha,\gamma,K)-strongly convex, and cond(f~)≤κ​(α,γ,ΘK)cond~𝑓𝜅𝛼𝛾subscriptΘ𝐾\operatorname*{cond}(\tilde{f})\leq\kappa(\alpha,\gamma,\Theta_{K}) where

κ​(α,γ,ΘK)≤(1−γ​(L+α)1−γ​(μ+α))K−1​Lμ.𝜅𝛼𝛾subscriptΘ𝐾superscript1𝛾𝐿𝛼1𝛾𝜇𝛼𝐾1𝐿𝜇\kappa(\alpha,\gamma,\Theta_{K})\leq\left(\dfrac{1-\gamma(L+\alpha)}{1-\gamma(\mu+\alpha)}\right)^{K-1}\dfrac{L}{\mu}. (13)

We show in Appendix B.3 that Lemmas 3 and 4 are tight. The extra condition that γ<(K​L+α)−1𝛾superscript𝐾𝐿𝛼1\gamma<(KL+\alpha)^{-1} for Θ=ΘKΘsubscriptΘ𝐾\Theta=\Theta_{K} is due to the fact that when γ≥(K​L+α)−1𝛾superscript𝐾𝐿𝛼1\gamma\geq(KL+\alpha)^{-1}, cond(f~​(x,α,γ,ΘK))cond~𝑓𝑥𝛼𝛾subscriptΘ𝐾\operatorname*{cond}(\tilde{f}(x,\alpha,\gamma,\Theta_{K})) depends on intermediate eigenvalues of the Aisubscript𝐴𝑖A_{i}, and exhibits more nuanced behavior. We explore this further in Section 5.

As K→1→𝐾1K\to 1 or γ→0→𝛾0\gamma\to 0, κ​(α,γ,ΘK)→L/μ→𝜅𝛼𝛾subscriptΘ𝐾𝐿𝜇\kappa(\alpha,\gamma,\Theta_{K})\to L/\mu, which bounds the condition number of the empirical loss f𝑓f. If γ𝛾\gamma is not close to 0, we get an exponential reduction (in terms of K𝐾K) of the condition number. While the analysis is not as clear for Θ1:KsubscriptΘ:1𝐾\Theta_{1:K}, one can show that κ​(α,γ,Θ1:K)≤L/μ𝜅𝛼𝛾subscriptΘ:1𝐾𝐿𝜇\kappa(\alpha,\gamma,\Theta_{1:K})\leq L/\mu, with equality if and only if α=0𝛼0\alpha=0, and either γ=0𝛾0\gamma=0 or K=1𝐾1K=1. Moreover, κ​(α,γ,Θ1:K)𝜅𝛼𝛾subscriptΘ:1𝐾\kappa(\alpha,\gamma,\Theta_{1:K}) decreases as K→∞→𝐾K\to\infty or γ→(L+α)−1→𝛾superscript𝐿𝛼1\gamma\to(L+\alpha)^{-1}. For both Θ1:KsubscriptΘ:1𝐾\Theta_{1:K} and ΘKsubscriptΘ𝐾\Theta_{K}, increasing α𝛼\alpha decreases κ𝜅\kappa.

Here we see the impact of local update methods on convergence: Popular methods such as FedAvg, FedProx, MAML, and Reptile reduce the condition number of the surrogate loss function they are actually optimizing. In the next section, we translate this into concrete convergence rates for LocalUpdate.

4.2 Convergence Rates

We now focus on a deterministic version of LocalUpdate in which all clients participate at each round and perform K𝐾K steps of gradient descent. The server updates its model using qt=𝔼i∼𝒫[qti]subscript𝑞𝑡subscript𝔼similar-to𝑖𝒫superscriptsubscript𝑞𝑡𝑖q_{t}=\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{i\sim\mathcal{P}}[q_{t}^{i}], where qtisuperscriptsubscript𝑞𝑡𝑖q_{t}^{i} is the output of ClientUpdate for client i𝑖i. In particular, 𝒫𝒫\mathcal{P} must be known to the server. In this case, Theorem 1 implies that qt=∇f~​(xt,α,γ,Θ)subscript𝑞𝑡∇~𝑓subscript𝑥𝑡𝛼𝛾Θq_{t}=\nabla\tilde{f}(x_{t},\alpha,\gamma,\Theta), so LocalUpdate is equivalent to applying ServerOpt to the true gradients of f~​(x,α,γ,Θ)~𝑓𝑥𝛼𝛾Θ\tilde{f}(x,\alpha,\gamma,\Theta).

We specialize to the setting where ServerOpt is gradient descent, with or without momentum (though our analysis can be directly extended to other optimizers). Thus, LocalUpdate is equivalent to gradient descent on f~​(x,α,γ,Θ)~𝑓𝑥𝛼𝛾Θ\tilde{f}(x,\alpha,\gamma,\Theta). Using the bound on cond(f~)cond~𝑓\operatorname*{cond}(\tilde{f}) in Lemma 2, we can directly apply classical convergence theory gradient descent (Lessard et al. (2016, Proposition 1) give a useful summary) to derive convergence rates for LocalUpdate. Similar analyses can be done in the stochastic setting.

Theorem 3.

Suppose γ<(L+α)−1𝛾superscript𝐿𝛼1\gamma<(L+\alpha)^{-1} and ServerOpt is gradient descent with Nesterov, heavy-ball, or no momentum. Then for some hyperparameter setting of ServerOpt, and ρ𝜌\rho as in Table 2, the iterates {xt}t≥1subscriptsubscript𝑥𝑡𝑡1\{x_{t}\}_{t\geq 1} of LocalUpdate satisfy

∥xT−x∗​(α,γ,Θ)∥≤ρT​∥x0−x∗​(α,γ,Θ)∥.delimited-∥∥subscript𝑥𝑇superscript𝑥𝛼𝛾Θsuperscript𝜌𝑇delimited-∥∥subscript𝑥0superscript𝑥𝛼𝛾Θ\left\lVert x_{T}-x^{*}(\alpha,\gamma,\Theta)\right\rVert\leq\rho^{T}\left\lVert x_{0}-x^{*}(\alpha,\gamma,\Theta)\right\rVert. (14)

Thus, (properly tuned) server momentum improves the convergence of LocalUpdate, giving theoretical grounding111Yuan and Ma (2020) first showed that momentum can accelerate FedAvg, though they use a different momentum scheme with extra per-round communication. to the improved convergence of FedAvgM shown by Hsu et al. (2019) and Reddi et al. (2020). Since ServerOpt does not change the surrogate loss, this improvement in convergence does not degrade the accuracy of the learned model.

Given the bounds on cond(f~)cond~𝑓\operatorname*{cond}(\tilde{f}) in (11) and (13), we obtain explicit convergence rates for FedAvg- and MAML-style algorithms as well. In particular, one can show that increasing γ𝛾\gamma or K𝐾K decreases κ𝜅\kappa (and therefore ρ𝜌\rho). We show in the next section that this comes at the expense of increasing the empirical loss.

4.3 Distance Between Global Minimizers

We now turn our attention towards the discrepancy between the surrogate loss f~~𝑓\tilde{f} and the empirical loss f𝑓f. We assume γ<(L+α)−1𝛾superscript𝐿𝛼1\gamma<(L+\alpha)^{-1}. By Lemma 1, f~~𝑓\tilde{f} and f𝑓f are strongly convex with global minimizers we denote by

x∗​(α,γ,Θ):=argminxf~​(x,α,γ,Θ),assignsuperscript𝑥𝛼𝛾Θsubscriptargmin𝑥~𝑓𝑥𝛼𝛾Θx^{*}(\alpha,\gamma,\Theta):=\operatorname*{argmin}_{x}\tilde{f}(x,\alpha,\gamma,\Theta),
x∗:=argminxf​(x).assignsuperscript𝑥subscriptargmin𝑥𝑓𝑥x^{*}:=\operatorname*{argmin}_{x}f(x).

We are interested in ‖x∗​(α,γ,Θ)−x∗‖normsuperscript𝑥𝛼𝛾Θsuperscript𝑥\|x^{*}(\alpha,\gamma,\Theta)-x^{*}\|. While we focus on the setting where 𝒫𝒫\mathcal{P} is a discrete distribution over some finite ℐℐ\mathcal{I}, our analysis can be generalized to arbitrary probability spaces (ℐ,ℱ,𝒫)ℐℱ𝒫(\mathcal{I},\mathcal{F},\mathcal{P}). We derive the following bound.

Lemma 5.

Let b=maxi∈ℐ⁡λmax​(Qi​(α,γ,Θ))𝑏subscript𝑖ℐsubscript𝜆subscript𝑄𝑖𝛼𝛾Θb=\max_{i\in\mathcal{I}}\lambda_{\max}(Q_{i}(\alpha,\gamma,\Theta)) and a=mini∈ℐ⁡λmin​(Qi​(α,γ,Θ))𝑎subscript𝑖ℐsubscript𝜆subscript𝑄𝑖𝛼𝛾Θa=\min_{i\in\mathcal{I}}\lambda_{\min}(Q_{i}(\alpha,\gamma,\Theta)). Then

‖x∗​(α,γ,Θ)−x∗‖≤8​C​b−ab+a.normsuperscript𝑥𝛼𝛾Θsuperscript𝑥8𝐶𝑏𝑎𝑏𝑎\|x^{*}(\alpha,\gamma,\Theta)-x^{*}\|\leq 8C\dfrac{\sqrt{b}-\sqrt{a}}{\sqrt{b}+\sqrt{a}}. (15)

When d=1𝑑1d=1, we can reduce the constant factor to 2​C2𝐶2C, which we show is tight (see Appendix C.2). While we conjecture that this bound holds with a constant of 2​C2𝐶2C for all d𝑑d, we leave this to future work.

Our proof technique for Lemma 5 may be of independent interest. We derive this result by first proving an analog of the Bhatia-Davis inequality (Bhatia and Davis, 2000) for mean absolute deviations of bounded random variables (Theorem 5 in Appendix C).

Let κ0:=L/μassignsubscript𝜅0𝐿𝜇\kappa_{0}:=L/\mu. Specializing to Θ=Θ1:KΘsubscriptΘ:1𝐾\Theta=\Theta_{1:K} or ΘKsubscriptΘ𝐾\Theta_{K}, we derive a link between κ​(α,γ,Θ)𝜅𝛼𝛾Θ\kappa(\alpha,\gamma,\Theta) in (11) and (13) and the distance between optimizers.

Lemma 6.

Suppose that either (I) γ<(L+α)−1𝛾superscript𝐿𝛼1\gamma<(L+\alpha)^{-1} and Θ=Θ1:KΘsubscriptΘ:1𝐾\Theta=\Theta_{1:K} or (II) γ<(K​L+α)−1𝛾superscript𝐾𝐿𝛼1\gamma<(KL+\alpha)^{-1} and Θ=ΘKΘsubscriptΘ𝐾\Theta=\Theta_{K}. Then for all i∈𝒫𝑖𝒫i\in\mathcal{P}, cond(Qi​(α,γ,Θ))≤κ0​κ​(α,γ,Θ)−1condsubscript𝑄𝑖𝛼𝛾Θsubscript𝜅0𝜅superscript𝛼𝛾Θ1\operatorname*{cond}(Q_{i}(\alpha,\gamma,\Theta))\leq\kappa_{0}\kappa(\alpha,\gamma,\Theta)^{-1}.

Combining this with Lemma 5, we get:

Theorem 4.

Under the same settings as Lemma 6,

‖x∗​(α,γ,Θ)−x∗‖≤8​C​κ0−κ​(α,γ,Θ)κ0+κ​(α,γ,Θ).normsuperscript𝑥𝛼𝛾Θsuperscript𝑥8𝐶subscript𝜅0𝜅𝛼𝛾Θsubscript𝜅0𝜅𝛼𝛾Θ\|x^{*}(\alpha,\gamma,\Theta)-x^{*}\|\leq 8C\frac{\sqrt{\kappa_{0}}-\sqrt{\kappa(\alpha,\gamma,\Theta)}}{\sqrt{\kappa_{0}}+\sqrt{\kappa(\alpha,\gamma,\Theta)}}. (16)

Applying Theorem 3, we bound the convergence of LocalUpdate to the empirical minimizer x∗superscript𝑥x^{*}.

Corollary 1.

Under the same settings as Theorem 3, for some hyperparameter setting of ServerOpt, the iterates {xt}t≥1subscriptsubscript𝑥𝑡𝑡1\{x_{t}\}_{t\geq 1} of LocalUpdate satisfy

∥xT−x∗∥≤ρT​∥x0−x∗​(α,γ,Θ)∥+8​C​κ0−κκ0+κdelimited-∥∥subscript𝑥𝑇superscript𝑥superscript𝜌𝑇delimited-∥∥subscript𝑥0superscript𝑥𝛼𝛾Θ8𝐶subscript𝜅0𝜅subscript𝜅0𝜅\displaystyle\left\lVert x_{T}-x^{*}\right\rVert\leq\rho^{T}\left\lVert x_{0}-x^{*}(\alpha,\gamma,\Theta)\right\rVert+8C\frac{\sqrt{\kappa_{0}}-\sqrt{\kappa}}{\sqrt{\kappa_{0}}+\sqrt{\kappa}}

where κ=κ​(α,γ,Θ)𝜅𝜅𝛼𝛾Θ\kappa=\kappa(\alpha,\gamma,\Theta) is given in (11) and (13), and ρ𝜌\rho is given in Table 2.

Here we see the benefit of local update methods in communication-limited settings. When T𝑇T is small and ∥x0−x∗∥delimited-∥∥subscript𝑥0superscript𝑥\left\lVert x_{0}-x^{*}\right\rVert is large, we can achieve better convergence by decreasing ρ𝜌\rho and leaving the second term fixed. In such settings, FedAvg can arrive at a neighborhood of a critical point in fewer communication rounds than mini-batch SGD, but may not ever actually reach the critical point. If ∥x0−x∗∥delimited-∥∥subscript𝑥0superscript𝑥\left\lVert x_{0}-x^{*}\right\rVert is small, we may be better served by using mini-batch SGD instead.

5 Comparing Local Update Methods

Comparing optimization algorithms is a fundamental theoretical effort. Many past works compare local update methods based on their convergence to critical points of the empirical loss. By Theorem 1, LocalUpdate is only guaranteed to converge to critical points of f𝑓f if γ=0𝛾0\gamma=0 or K​(Θ)=1𝐾Θ1K(\Theta)=1. Thus, existing analyses ignore many useful cases of LocalUpdate.

To remedy this, we compare local update algorithms on the basis of both convergence and accuracy. Instead of fixing γ𝛾\gamma and ΘΘ\Theta, we analyze LocalUpdate as γ𝛾\gamma and K​(Θ)𝐾ΘK(\Theta) vary. To do so, we use our theory from Section 4. Given α,γ𝛼𝛾\alpha,\gamma and ΘΘ\Theta, we define the convergence rate ρ​(α,γ,Θ)𝜌𝛼𝛾Θ\rho(\alpha,\gamma,\Theta) as the infimum over all ρ𝜌\rho such that for all T≥1𝑇1T\geq 1, (14) holds. Values of ρ𝜌\rho when ServerOpt is gradient descent are given in Table 2. For Θ=Θ1:KΘsubscriptΘ:1𝐾\Theta=\Theta_{1:K} or ΘKsubscriptΘ𝐾\Theta_{K}, we define the suboptimality Δ​(α,γ,Θ)Δ𝛼𝛾Θ\Delta(\alpha,\gamma,\Theta) by

Δ​(α,γ,Θ):=κ0−κ​(α,γ,Θ)κ0+κ(α,γ,Θ.\Delta(\alpha,\gamma,\Theta):=\dfrac{\sqrt{\kappa_{0}}-\sqrt{\kappa(\alpha,\gamma,\Theta)}}{\sqrt{\kappa_{0}}+\sqrt{\kappa(\alpha,\gamma,\Theta}}. (17)

By Theorem 4, this captures the asymptotic worst-case suboptimality of LocalUpdate.

Note that ρ,Δ∈[0,1]𝜌Δ01\rho,\Delta\in[0,1]. Therefore, fixing μ,L𝜇𝐿\mu,L and ServerOpt, we obtain a Pareto frontier in [0,1]2superscript012[0,1]^{2} by plotting (ρ,Δ)𝜌Δ(\rho,\Delta) for various γ𝛾\gamma and K​(Θ)𝐾ΘK(\Theta). This curve represents the worst-case convergence/accuracy trade-off of a class of local update methods. We generally want the curve to be as close to (0,0)00(0,0) as possible.

For example, in Figure 1 we let ServerOpt be gradient descent and set α=0,Θ=Θ1:Kformulae-sequence𝛼0ΘsubscriptΘ:1𝐾\alpha=0,\Theta=\Theta_{1:K}. We plot (ρ,Δ)𝜌Δ(\rho,\Delta) as we vary K𝐾K and fix γ𝛾\gamma, and vice-versa. When L=5𝐿5L=5, we obtain nearly identical curves. The curves for L=50𝐿50L=50 are similar, except that when we fix K𝐾K and vary γ𝛾\gamma, we do not reach ρ≈0𝜌0\rho\approx 0. While γ𝛾\gamma and K𝐾K have similar impacts on convergence-accuracy trade-offs, varying K𝐾K leads a larger set of attainable (ρ,Δ)𝜌Δ(\rho,\Delta). Formally, this is because in (11), limγ→L−1(κ)≠0subscript→𝛾superscript𝐿1𝜅0\lim_{\gamma\to L^{-1}}(\kappa)\neq 0. Intuitively, K→∞→𝐾K\to\infty recovers one-shot averaging while γ→L−1→𝛾superscript𝐿1\gamma\to L^{-1} does not. Notably, the convergence-accuracy trade-off becomes closer to a linear trade-off as L/μ𝐿𝜇L/\mu decreases.

The Pareto frontiers contain more information than just the convergence rate to a critical point (the curve’s intersection with the x𝑥x-axis). This information is useful in communication-limited regimes, where we wish to minimize the number of rounds needed to attain a given accuracy. The curves also help visualize various hyperparameter settings of an algorithms simultaneously. To illustrate this, we use the Pareto frontiers to derive novel findings regarding server momentum, proximal client updates, and qualitative differences between FedAvg and MAML. The results are all given below. For more results, see Appendix D.

Impact of Server Momentum

As shown empirically by Hsu et al. (2019) and as reflected in Table 2, server momentum can improve convergence. To understand this, in Figure 2 we compare Pareto frontiers where Θ=Θ1:KΘsubscriptΘ:1𝐾\Theta=\Theta_{1:K} and ServerOpt is gradient descent with various types of momentum (Nesterov, heavy-ball, or no momentum). We see a strict ordering of the server optimization methods. Heavy-ball momentum is better than Nesterov momentum, which is better than no momentum.

One important finding is that the benefit of momentum is more pronounced as L/μ𝐿𝜇L/\mu increases. On the other hand, the benefit of server momentum diminishes for sufficiently large K𝐾K: In Figure 4, the various types of momentum lead to similar suboptimality when the convergence rate is close to 0. Intuitively, as K→∞→𝐾K\to\infty, we recover one-shot averaging, which converges in a single communication round with or without momentum.

Another intriguing observation: The Pareto frontiers for heavy-ball momentum appear to be symmetric about the line ρ=Δ𝜌Δ\rho=\Delta. We conjecture this is true for any μ,L𝜇𝐿\mu,L. While we believe that this may be provable by careful algebraic manipulation of our results above, ideally a proof would explain the root causes of this symmetry. Thus, we leave a proof to future work.

Proximal Client Updates

So far we have only considered α=0𝛼0\alpha=0. One might posit that as α𝛼\alpha varies, the Pareto frontier moves closer to the origin. This appears to not be the case. In all settings we examined, changing α𝛼\alpha did not bring the Pareto frontier closer to 00. Instead, the frontier for α>0𝛼0\alpha>0 was simply a subset of the frontier for α=0𝛼0\alpha=0.

To illustrate this, we plot Pareto frontiers for varying α𝛼\alpha in Figure 3. As α𝛼\alpha increases, the frontier becomes a smaller subset of the frontier for α=0𝛼0\alpha=0. Thus, proximal client updates may not enable faster convergence. Rather, their benefit may be in guarding against setting γ𝛾\gamma too small or K𝐾K too large. Figure 3 shows that FedAvg can always attain the same (ρ,Δ)𝜌Δ(\rho,\Delta) as FedProx, but it may require different hyperparameters. The reverse is not true, as FedProx cannot recover one-shot averaging. Our findings are consistent with work by Wang et al. (2020), who show that FedProx can reduce the “objective inconsistency” of FedAvg, at the expense of increasing convergence time.

Comparing MAML to FedAvg

We now turn our attention to comparing FedAvg-style algorithms (Θ=Θ1:KΘsubscriptΘ:1𝐾\Theta=\Theta_{1:K}) to MAML-style algorithms (Θ=ΘK)\Theta=\Theta_{K}). We plot Pareto frontiers for the ρ,Δ𝜌Δ\rho,\Delta guaranteed by Theorems 3 and 4. The results are in Figure 4.

For each ServerOpt, the MAML frontier is a subset of the FedAvg frontier. Recall that in Theorem 3, we require γ<(L+α)−1𝛾superscript𝐿𝛼1\gamma<(L+\alpha)^{-1} for FedAvg, but γ<(K​L+α)−1𝛾superscript𝐾𝐿𝛼1\gamma<(KL+\alpha)^{-1} for MAML. In Figure 4 this causes the frontier for ΘKsubscriptΘ𝐾\Theta_{K} to be more restrictive than for Θ1:KsubscriptΘ:1𝐾\Theta_{1:K}. However, it is still notable that these two fundamentally different methods, attain the same frontier when ρ𝜌\rho is large.

By Lemma 1, ρ𝜌\rho and ΔΔ\Delta are still well-defined for ΘKsubscriptΘ𝐾\Theta_{K} when (K​L+α)−1≤γ<(L+α)−1superscript𝐾𝐿𝛼1𝛾superscript𝐿𝛼1(KL+\alpha)^{-1}\leq\gamma<(L+\alpha)^{-1}. To understand what happens in this regime, we generate random symmetric A∈ℝd×d𝐴superscriptℝ𝑑𝑑A\in\mathbb{R}^{d\times d} satisfying cond(A)=L/μcond𝐴𝐿𝜇\operatorname*{cond}(A)=L/\mu and compute Q​(α,γ,ΘK)𝑄𝛼𝛾subscriptΘ𝐾Q(\alpha,\gamma,\Theta_{K}) as in (6). We then compute κ𝜅\kappa via (9), and plug this into Table 2 and (17) to get ρ,Δ𝜌Δ\rho,\Delta. This gives us a simulated Pareto frontier for ΘKsubscriptΘ𝐾\Theta_{K}, which we compare to Θ1:KsubscriptΘ:1𝐾\Theta_{1:K} in Figure 5. For details and additional experiments, see Appendix D.1.

The Pareto frontiers are identical for small K𝐾K (mirroring Figure 4), but diverge when γ≥(K​L+α)−1𝛾superscript𝐾𝐿𝛼1\gamma\geq(KL+\alpha)^{-1}. The frontier for MAML then moves further from 0. Intuitively, FedAvg tries to learn a global model, while MAML tries to learn a model that adapts quickly to new tasks (Finn et al., 2017); MAML need not minimize (ρ,Δ)𝜌Δ(\rho,\Delta). The MAML frontier is noisy for d=5𝑑5d=5 (as ρ𝜌\rho, ΔΔ\Delta depend on random eigenvalues of A𝐴A), but stabilizes for d=100𝑑100d=100. While we posit that this reflects a semi-circle law for eigenvalues of random matrices (Alon et al., 2002), we leave an analysis to future work.

One final observation that highlights the similarities and differences of FedAvg- and MAML-style methods: In Figure 4, the curve for MAML when d=100𝑑100d=100 has a clear cusp. This seems to occur at the same suboptimality (ie. y𝑦y-value) as the intersection of the FedAvg curve with the y𝑦y-axis. In other words, the behavior of MAML diverges substantially from FedAvg, but only after it reaches the same suboptimality as FedAvg for K→∞→𝐾K\to\infty (which corresponds to one-shot averaging). We are unsure why the suboptimality of one-shot averaging corresponds to a cuspidal operating point of MAML, but this observation highlights significant nuance in the behavior of these methods.

6 Limitations and Discussion

Our convergence-accuracy framework and the resulting Pareto frontiers can be useful tools in understanding how algorithmic choices impact local update methods. The obvious limitation is that they only apply to quadratic models. While this is restrictive, we show empirically in Appendix F that even for non-convex functions, the client learning rate governs a convergence-accuracy trade-off for FedAvg.

Our framework may also be useful in identifying important phenomena underlying LocalUpdate, even in non-quadratic settings. To demonstrate this, we show that many of the observations in Section 5 hold in non-convex settings. We train a CNN on the FEMNIST dataset (Caldas et al., 2018) using LocalUpdate where Θ=Θ1:50ΘsubscriptΘ:150\Theta=\Theta_{1:50}. We tune client and server learning rates. See Appendix E for full details. In Figure 6, we illustrate how server momentum and α𝛼\alpha change convergence. Our results match the Pareto frontiers in Figures 2 and 3: Server momentum improves convergence, while α𝛼\alpha has little to no effect, provided we tune learning rates.

This brief example illustrates that our framework can identify crucial facets of local update methods. While our framework may not capture all relevant details of such methods, we believe it greatly simplifies their analysis, comparison, and design. In the future, we hope to extend this framework to more general loss functions. Other important extensions include stochastic settings with partial client participation, as well as trade-offs between convergence and post-adaptation accuracy of local update methods.

Appendix A Relations between FedAvg, FedProx, and LocalUpdate

We focus on the following (simplified) version of FedAvg, otherwise known as Local SGD (Zinkevich et al., 2010; Stich, 2019): At each iteration t𝑡t, we sample some set of clients Itsubscript𝐼𝑡I_{t} of size M𝑀M from the client population ℐℐ\mathcal{I}. Each client i∈It𝑖subscript𝐼𝑡i\in I_{t} receives the server’s model xtsubscript𝑥𝑡x_{t}, and applies K𝐾K steps of mini-batch SGD to its local model, resulting in an updated local model xtisuperscriptsubscript𝑥𝑡𝑖x_{t}^{i}. The server receives these models from the sampled clients, and updates its model via

xt+1=1M​∑i∈Itxti.subscript𝑥𝑡11𝑀subscript𝑖subscript𝐼𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑡𝑖x_{t+1}=\dfrac{1}{M}\sum_{i\in I_{t}}x_{t}^{i}.

Fix t𝑡t, and let gkisuperscriptsubscript𝑔𝑘𝑖g_{k}^{i} denote the k𝑘k-th mini-batch gradient of client i𝑖i. Suppose we use a learning rate of γ𝛾\gamma on each client when performing mini-batch SGD. Then we have

xt+1subscript𝑥𝑡1\displaystyle x_{t+1} =1M​∑i∈Itxtiabsent1𝑀subscript𝑖subscript𝐼𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑡𝑖\displaystyle=\dfrac{1}{M}\sum_{i\in I_{t}}x_{t}^{i}
=xt−1M​∑i∈It(xt−xti)absentsubscript𝑥𝑡1𝑀subscript𝑖subscript𝐼𝑡subscript𝑥𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑡𝑖\displaystyle=x_{t}-\dfrac{1}{M}\sum_{i\in I_{t}}\left(x_{t}-x_{t}^{i}\right)
=xt−1M​∑i∈Itxt−(xt−γ​∑k=1Kgki)absentsubscript𝑥𝑡1𝑀subscript𝑖subscript𝐼𝑡subscript𝑥𝑡subscript𝑥𝑡𝛾superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑔𝑘𝑖\displaystyle=x_{t}-\dfrac{1}{M}\sum_{i\in I_{t}}x_{t}-\left(x_{t}-\gamma\sum_{k=1}^{K}g_{k}^{i}\right)
=xt−γ​1M​∑i∈It∑k=1Kgki.absentsubscript𝑥𝑡𝛾1𝑀subscript𝑖subscript𝐼𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑔𝑘𝑖\displaystyle=x_{t}-\gamma\dfrac{1}{M}\sum_{i\in I_{t}}\sum_{k=1}^{K}g_{k}^{i}.

A similar analysis holds for FedProx, but with the usage of a proximal term with parameter α>0𝛼0\alpha>0. In both cases, this is exactly LocalUpdate (see Algorithms 1 and 2) with Θ=Θ1:KΘsubscriptΘ:1𝐾\Theta=\Theta_{1:K}, η=γ𝜂𝛾\eta=\gamma, and where ServerOpt is gradient descent. However, by instead using a server learning rate of η𝜂\eta that is allowed to vary independently of γ𝛾\gamma in LocalUpdate, we can obtain markedly different convergence behavior. We note that a form of this decoupling has previously been explored by Karimireddy et al. (2019) and Reddi et al. (2020). However, these versions instead perform averaging on the so-called “model delta”, in which the server model is updated via

xt+1subscript𝑥𝑡1\displaystyle x_{t+1} =xt−ηM​∑i∈It(xt−xti)absentsubscript𝑥𝑡𝜂𝑀subscript𝑖subscript𝐼𝑡subscript𝑥𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑡𝑖\displaystyle=x_{t}-\dfrac{\eta}{M}\sum_{i\in I_{t}}(x_{t}-x_{t}^{i})
=xt−ηM​∑i∈It(xt−(xt−γ​∑k=1Kgki))absentsubscript𝑥𝑡𝜂𝑀subscript𝑖subscript𝐼𝑡subscript𝑥𝑡subscript𝑥𝑡𝛾superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑔𝑘𝑖\displaystyle=x_{t}-\dfrac{\eta}{M}\sum_{i\in I_{t}}\left(x_{t}-\left(x_{t}-\gamma\sum_{k=1}^{K}g_{k}^{i}\right)\right)
=xt−η​γM​∑i∈It∑k=1Kgki.absentsubscript𝑥𝑡𝜂𝛾𝑀subscript𝑖subscript𝐼𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑔𝑘𝑖\displaystyle=x_{t}-\dfrac{\eta\gamma}{M}\sum_{i\in I_{t}}\sum_{k=1}^{K}g_{k}^{i}.

Thus, while this does decouple η𝜂\eta and γ𝛾\gamma to some degree, it does not fully do so. In particular, if we set γ=0𝛾0\gamma=0, then xt+1=xtsubscript𝑥𝑡1subscript𝑥𝑡x_{t+1}=x_{t}, in which case we can make no progress overall. This is particularly important because, as implied by Theorem 1, for K​(Θ)>1𝐾Θ1K(\Theta)>1 we can only guarantee that the surrogate loss has the same critical points as the true loss by setting γ=0𝛾0\gamma=0. More generally, we see that the effective learning rate used in the model-delta approach is the product η​γ𝜂𝛾\eta\gamma. This can result in conflations between the effect of changing the server learning rate γ𝛾\gamma and changing the client learning rate η𝜂\eta. By disentangling these, we can better understand differences in the impact of these parameters on the underlying optimization dynamics.

B.2 Proofs of Lemmas 1, 2, 3, 4, and 6

These lemmas will follow from a spectral analysis of Qi​(α,γ,Θ)subscript𝑄𝑖𝛼𝛾ΘQ_{i}(\alpha,\gamma,\Theta). We defer the proof of Lemma 5 to Appendix C due to its more elaborate nature. We first state a general result about eigenvalues of expected values of matrices.

Lemma 8.

Suppose we have a probability space (Ω,ℱ,𝒫)Ωℱ𝒫(\Omega,\mathcal{F},\mathcal{P}) where ΩΩ\Omega is the set of symmetric matrices in ℝd×dsuperscriptℝ𝑑𝑑\mathbb{R}^{d\times d}, and let B𝐵B be a random matrix drawn from 𝒫𝒫\mathcal{P}. Suppose that 𝔼[B]𝔼𝐵\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}[B] exists and is finite. Define

τ1:=𝔼[λmin​(B)],τ2:=𝔼[λmax​(B)].formulae-sequenceassignsubscript𝜏1𝔼subscript𝜆𝐵assignsubscript𝜏2𝔼subscript𝜆𝐵\tau_{1}:=\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}[\lambda_{\min}(B)],~{}~{}\tau_{2}:=\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}[\lambda_{\max}(B)].

Then τ1​I⪯𝔼[B]⪯τ2​Iprecedes-or-equalssubscript𝜏1𝐼𝔼𝐵precedes-or-equalssubscript𝜏2𝐼\tau_{1}I\preceq\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}[B]\preceq\tau_{2}I.

Proof.

By standard properties of expectations, 𝔼[B]𝔼𝐵\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}[B] is a symmetric matrix. Fix v∈ℝd𝑣superscriptℝ𝑑v\in\mathbb{R}^{d} such that ∥v∥=1delimited-∥∥𝑣1\left\lVert v\right\rVert=1. By the linearity of expectation,

v⊺​𝔼[B]⁡v=𝔼[v⊺​B​v]≤𝔼[λmax​(B)].superscript𝑣⊺𝔼𝐵𝑣𝔼superscript𝑣⊺𝐵𝑣𝔼subscript𝜆𝐵v^{\intercal}\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}[B]v=\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}[v^{\intercal}Bv]\leq\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}[\lambda_{\max}(B)].

An analogous argument shows v⊺​𝔼[B]⁡v≥𝔼[λmin​(B)]superscript𝑣⊺𝔼𝐵𝑣𝔼subscript𝜆𝐵v^{\intercal}\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}[B]v\geq\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}[\lambda_{\min}(B)]. The result follows. ∎

We also compute the spectrum of Qi​(α,γ,Θ)subscript𝑄𝑖𝛼𝛾ΘQ_{i}(\alpha,\gamma,\Theta) and QI​(α,γ,Θ)​Aisubscript𝑄𝐼𝛼𝛾Θsubscript𝐴𝑖Q_{I}(\alpha,\gamma,\Theta)A_{i}.

Lemma 9.

For each eigenvalue λ𝜆\lambda of Aisubscript𝐴𝑖A_{i}, Qi​(α,γ,Θ)subscript𝑄𝑖𝛼𝛾ΘQ_{i}(\alpha,\gamma,\Theta) has an eigenvalue

∑k=1K​(Θ)θk​(1−γ​(λ+α))k−1superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾Θsubscript𝜃𝑘superscript1𝛾𝜆𝛼𝑘1\sum_{k=1}^{K(\Theta)}\theta_{k}(1-\gamma(\lambda+\alpha))^{k-1} (29)

and Qi​(α,γ,Θ)​Aisubscript𝑄𝑖𝛼𝛾Θsubscript𝐴𝑖Q_{i}(\alpha,\gamma,\Theta)A_{i} has an eigenvalue

∑k=1K​(Θ)θk​(1−γ​(λ+α))k−1​λ,superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾Θsubscript𝜃𝑘superscript1𝛾𝜆𝛼𝑘1𝜆\sum_{k=1}^{K(\Theta)}\theta_{k}(1-\gamma(\lambda+\alpha))^{k-1}\lambda, (30)

both with the same multiplicity as λ𝜆\lambda.

Proof.

Let v𝑣v be an eigenvector of Aisubscript𝐴𝑖A_{i} with eigenvalue λ𝜆\lambda. Then v𝑣v is an eigenvector of (I−γ​(Ai+α​I))k−1superscript𝐼𝛾subscript𝐴𝑖𝛼𝐼𝑘1(I-\gamma(A_{i}+\alpha I))^{k-1} with eigenvalue (1−γ​(λ+α))k−1superscript1𝛾𝜆𝛼𝑘1(1-\gamma(\lambda+\alpha))^{k-1}, implying (29) is an eigenvalue of Qi​(α,γ,Θ)subscript𝑄𝑖𝛼𝛾ΘQ_{i}(\alpha,\gamma,\Theta) with eigenvector v𝑣v. Similarly, we note that v𝑣v is an eigenvector of (I−γ​(Ai+α​I))k−1​Aisuperscript𝐼𝛾subscript𝐴𝑖𝛼𝐼𝑘1subscript𝐴𝑖(I-\gamma(A_{i}+\alpha I))^{k-1}A_{i} with eigenvalue (1−γ​(λ+α))k−1​λsuperscript1𝛾𝜆𝛼𝑘1𝜆(1-\gamma(\lambda+\alpha))^{k-1}\lambda, implying (30) is an eigenvalue of Qi​(α,γ,Θ)​Aisubscript𝑄𝑖𝛼𝛾Θsubscript𝐴𝑖Q_{i}(\alpha,\gamma,\Theta)A_{i} with eigenvector v𝑣v. The statement about multiplicities follows directly. ∎

Lemma 9 can be used in a straightforward manner to prove Lemma 1, which we restate and prove below.

See 1

Proof.

By Assumption 1, we have that for every eigenvalue λ𝜆\lambda of Aisubscript𝐴𝑖A_{i}, λ≤L𝜆𝐿\lambda\leq L. Therefore, for any such λ𝜆\lambda,

1−γ​(λ+α)≥1−γ​(L+α)>0.1𝛾𝜆𝛼1𝛾𝐿𝛼01-\gamma(\lambda+\alpha)\geq 1-\gamma(L+\alpha)>0.

Since the θksubscript𝜃𝑘\theta_{k} are nonnegative and not all zero by assumption, we see that (29) is a sum of nonnegative terms, at least one of which must be positive. Therefore, all eigenvalues of Qi​(α,γ,Θ)subscript𝑄𝑖𝛼𝛾ΘQ_{i}(\alpha,\gamma,\Theta) are positive, and Qi​(α,γ,Θ)subscript𝑄𝑖𝛼𝛾ΘQ_{i}(\alpha,\gamma,\Theta) is therefore symmetric and positive definite.

By Assumption 1, Aisubscript𝐴𝑖A_{i} is also symmetric and positive definite, hence the product Qi​(α,γ,Θ)​Aisubscript𝑄𝑖𝛼𝛾Θsubscript𝐴𝑖Q_{i}(\alpha,\gamma,\Theta)A_{i} is symmetric positive definite. However, since

∇x2f~i​(x,α,γ,Θ)=Qi​(α,γ,Θ)​Ai≻0subscriptsuperscript∇2𝑥subscript~𝑓𝑖𝑥𝛼𝛾Θsubscript𝑄𝑖𝛼𝛾Θsubscript𝐴𝑖succeeds0\nabla^{2}_{x}\tilde{f}_{i}(x,\alpha,\gamma,\Theta)=Q_{i}(\alpha,\gamma,\Theta)A_{i}\succ 0

we see that f~isubscript~𝑓𝑖\tilde{f}_{i} is a strongly convex quadratic function. ∎

We can also use 9 to derive Lemma 2. In fact, we will show a slightly stronger version, where we also bound the Lipschitz and strong convexity parameters of f~~𝑓\tilde{f}.

Lemma 10.

Suppose γ<(L+α)−1𝛾superscript𝐿𝛼1\gamma<(L+\alpha)^{-1}. Define

L~​(α,γ,Θ):=𝔼i[λmax​(Qi​(α,γ,Θ)​Ai)],assign~𝐿𝛼𝛾Θsubscript𝔼𝑖subscript𝜆subscript𝑄𝑖𝛼𝛾Θsubscript𝐴𝑖\tilde{L}(\alpha,\gamma,\Theta):=\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{i}[\lambda_{\max}(Q_{i}(\alpha,\gamma,\Theta)A_{i})], (31)
μ~​(α,γ,Θ):=𝔼[λmin​(Qi​(α,γ,Θ)​Ai)].assign~𝜇𝛼𝛾Θ𝔼subscript𝜆subscript𝑄𝑖𝛼𝛾Θsubscript𝐴𝑖\tilde{\mu}(\alpha,\gamma,\Theta):=\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}[\lambda_{\min}(Q_{i}(\alpha,\gamma,\Theta)A_{i})]. (32)

Then f~​(α,γ,Θ)~𝑓𝛼𝛾Θ\tilde{f}(\alpha,\gamma,\Theta) is L~​(α,γ,Θ)~𝐿𝛼𝛾Θ\tilde{L}(\alpha,\gamma,\Theta)-Lipschitz and μ~​(α,γ,Θ)~𝜇𝛼𝛾Θ\tilde{\mu}(\alpha,\gamma,\Theta)-strongly convex.

Proof.

Recall that the smoothness and strong convexity parameters of are the largest and smallest eigenvalue of its Hessian. Therefore, it suffices to bound the eigenvalues of f~​(α,γ,Θ)~𝑓𝛼𝛾Θ\tilde{f}(\alpha,\gamma,\Theta). By (7), we have

∇2f~i​(x,α,γ,Θ)=Qi​(α,γ,Θ)​Ai.superscript∇2subscript~𝑓𝑖𝑥𝛼𝛾Θsubscript𝑄𝑖𝛼𝛾Θsubscript𝐴𝑖\nabla^{2}\tilde{f}_{i}(x,\alpha,\gamma,\Theta)=Q_{i}(\alpha,\gamma,\Theta)A_{i}.

By (8), we also have

∇2f~​(α,γ,Θ)=𝔼i[∇2f~i​(α,γ,Θ)]=𝔼i[Qi​(α,γ,Θ)​Ai].superscript∇2~𝑓𝛼𝛾Θsubscript𝔼𝑖superscript∇2subscript~𝑓𝑖𝛼𝛾Θsubscript𝔼𝑖subscript𝑄𝑖𝛼𝛾Θsubscript𝐴𝑖\nabla^{2}\tilde{f}(\alpha,\gamma,\Theta)=\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{i}[\nabla^{2}\tilde{f}_{i}(\alpha,\gamma,\Theta)]=\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{i}[Q_{i}(\alpha,\gamma,\Theta)A_{i}].

Applying Lemma 8, we conclude the proof. ∎

Note that κ​(α,γ,Θ)𝜅𝛼𝛾Θ\kappa(\alpha,\gamma,\Theta) in (9) is simply the ratio of L~​(α,γ,Θ)~𝐿𝛼𝛾Θ\tilde{L}(\alpha,\gamma,\Theta) to μ~​(α,γ,Θ)~𝜇𝛼𝛾Θ\tilde{\mu}(\alpha,\gamma,\Theta), so we immediately derive Lemma 2 as a corollary to Lemma 10. Lemmas 3 and 4 are also straightforward consequences of Lemma 10, as we show below. For posterity, we state and prove each one separately.

Recall that as in (10), we define

ϕ​(λ,α,γ,K):=∑k=1K(1−γ​(λ+α))k−1​λ.assignitalic-ϕ𝜆𝛼𝛾𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾superscript1𝛾𝜆𝛼𝑘1𝜆\phi(\lambda,\alpha,\gamma,K):=\sum_{k=1}^{K}(1-\gamma(\lambda+\alpha))^{k-1}\lambda.

We can now restate and prove Lemma 3.

See 3

Proof.

∎

To prove Lemma 5, we will reduce it to a statement about mean absolute deviations of bounded random variables. We define the mean absolute deviation of a random variable below.

Definition 1.

Let X𝑋X be a random variable in some Banach space over ℝℝ\mathbb{R}. The mean absolute deviation of X𝑋X is

D​(X):=𝔼[∥X−𝔼[X]∥].assign𝐷𝑋𝔼delimited-∥∥𝑋𝔼𝑋D(X):=\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}[\left\lVert X-\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}[X]\right\rVert].

C.1 One-dimensional Case

We first proceed for d=1𝑑1d=1, so that Qi​(α,γ,Θ),Ai,ci∈ℝsubscript𝑄𝑖𝛼𝛾Θsubscript𝐴𝑖subscript𝑐𝑖ℝQ_{i}(\alpha,\gamma,\Theta),A_{i},c_{i}\in\mathbb{R}. We do this both for expository purposes, as when d=1𝑑1d=1 we can rely on classical versions of the mean absolute deviation, and because we actually derive tight bounds for d=1𝑑1d=1.

To derive our results, we bound the mean absolute deviation of bounded random variables. Our result is inspired by the bound by Bhatia and Davis (2000) on the variance of bounded random variables.

Theorem 5.

Suppose X𝑋X is a discrete random variable taking values in [a,b]⊆ℝ𝑎𝑏ℝ[a,b]\subseteq\mathbb{R} for a<b𝑎𝑏a<b. Then

D​(x)≤2​(b−𝔼[X])​(𝔼[X]−a)b−a.𝐷𝑥2𝑏𝔼𝑋𝔼𝑋𝑎𝑏𝑎D(x)\leq\dfrac{2(b-\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}[X])(\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}[X]-a)}{b-a}.

Moreover, this holds with equality iff X𝑋X is supported on {a,b}𝑎𝑏\{a,b\}.

A thorough examination of the derivation above shows that this inequality is strict if and only if x1∈(a,b)subscript𝑥1𝑎𝑏x_{1}\in(a,b) and p1>0subscript𝑝10p_{1}>0. Thus, D​(X′)≥D​(X)𝐷superscript𝑋′𝐷𝑋D(X^{\prime})\geq D(X) and X′superscript𝑋′X^{\prime} has one fewer possible outcome in the range (a,b)𝑎𝑏(a,b).

By iterating this procedure, (which is guaranteed to terminate after at most n𝑛n iterations), we obtain some random variable Y𝑌Y supported on {a,b}𝑎𝑏\{a,b\} such that D​(X)≤D​(Y)𝐷𝑋𝐷𝑌D(X)\leq D(Y), with equality if and only if X𝑋X is already supported on {a,b}𝑎𝑏\{a,b\}. Suppose Y𝑌Y takes on a,b𝑎𝑏a,b with probabilities (1−p),p1𝑝𝑝(1-p),p. Straightforward calculation shows

D​(Y)=2​(1−p)​p​(b−a)=2​(b−𝔼[X])​(𝔼[X]−a)b−a.𝐷𝑌21𝑝𝑝𝑏𝑎2𝑏𝔼𝑋𝔼𝑋𝑎𝑏𝑎D(Y)=2(1-p)p(b-a)=\dfrac{2(b-\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}[X])(\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}[X]-a)}{b-a}.

∎

Using the fact that for any real x𝑥x, (b−a)2≥4​(b−x)​(x−a)superscript𝑏𝑎24𝑏𝑥𝑥𝑎(b-a)^{2}\geq 4(b-x)(x-a) (with equality iff x=(b+a)/2𝑥𝑏𝑎2x=(b+a)/2) we arrive at the following corollary, analogous to Popoviciu’s inequality on variances (Popoviciu, 1935).

Corollary 2.

If X𝑋X is a discrete random variable on [a,b]𝑎𝑏[a,b], then

D​(x)≤12​(b−a),𝐷𝑥12𝑏𝑎D(x)\leq\frac{1}{2}(b-a),

with equality iff X𝑋X takes on the values a𝑎a and b𝑏b, each with probability 1/2121/2.

We can now prove a stronger version of Lemma 5 when d=1𝑑1d=1. For simplicity, we assume 𝒫𝒫\mathcal{P} is a discrete distribution on some finite ℐℐ\mathcal{I}, though the analysis can be generalized to arbitrary distributions.

Let b=maxi∈ℐ⁡λmax​(Qi​(α,γ,Θ))𝑏subscript𝑖ℐsubscript𝜆subscript𝑄𝑖𝛼𝛾Θb=\max_{i\in\mathcal{I}}\lambda_{\max}(Q_{i}(\alpha,\gamma,\Theta)), a=mini∈ℐ⁡λmin​(Qi​(α,γ,Θ))𝑎subscript𝑖ℐsubscript𝜆subscript𝑄𝑖𝛼𝛾Θa=\min_{i\in\mathcal{I}}\lambda_{\min}(Q_{i}(\alpha,\gamma,\Theta)). Then for d=1𝑑1d=1,

C.2 Tightness of Lemma 12

C.3 General Case

In this case, we will use a similar proof strategy. However, we will use a matrix-weighted version of the mean absolute deviation. Suppose we have positive-definite symmetric matrices X1,…,Xn,Y1,…​Yn∈ℝd×dsubscript𝑋1…subscript𝑋𝑛subscript𝑌1…subscript𝑌𝑛superscriptℝ𝑑𝑑X_{1},\dots,X_{n},Y_{1},\dots Y_{n}\in\mathbb{R}^{d\times d} such that for all i𝑖i, Xisubscript𝑋𝑖X_{i} and Yisubscript𝑌𝑖Y_{i} commute. Let Y=∑i=1nYi𝑌superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscript𝑌𝑖Y=\sum_{i=1}^{n}Y_{i}.

Definition 2.

The matrix-weighted mean of {X1,…​Xn}subscript𝑋1…subscript𝑋𝑛\{X_{1},\dots X_{n}\} with respect to {Y1,…​Yn}subscript𝑌1…subscript𝑌𝑛\{Y_{1},\dots Y_{n}\} is given by

f​(X1,…,Xn|Y1,…,Yn):=(∑i=1nXi​Yi)​Y−1.assign𝑓subscript𝑋1…conditionalsubscript𝑋𝑛subscript𝑌1…subscript𝑌𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscript𝑋𝑖subscript𝑌𝑖superscript𝑌1f(X_{1},\dots,X_{n}|Y_{1},\dots,Y_{n}):=\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n}X_{i}Y_{i}\right)Y^{-1}.

When d=1𝑑1d=1, and the Yi>0subscript𝑌𝑖0Y_{i}>0, this gives the standard mean of a discrete random variable X𝑋X taking values X1,…​Xnsubscript𝑋1…subscript𝑋𝑛X_{1},\dots X_{n} with probabilities Y1,…​Ynsubscript𝑌1…subscript𝑌𝑛Y_{1},\dots Y_{n}. When the context is clear, we will simply denote this by f​(X|Y)𝑓conditional𝑋𝑌f(X|Y). We first prove a simple lemma regarding the Loewner ordering and matrix-weighted means.

Lemma 13.

Suppose that for all i𝑖i, a​I⪯Xi⪯b​Iprecedes-or-equals𝑎𝐼subscript𝑋𝑖precedes-or-equals𝑏𝐼aI\preceq X_{i}\preceq bI. Then a​I⪯f​(X|Y)⪯b​Iprecedes-or-equals𝑎𝐼𝑓conditional𝑋𝑌precedes-or-equals𝑏𝐼aI\preceq f(X|Y)\preceq bI.

This generalizes the fact that if X𝑋X is a random variable taking values in [a,b]𝑎𝑏[a,b], then a≤𝔼[X]≤b𝑎𝔼𝑋𝑏a\leq\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}[X]\leq b to symmetric positive-definite matrices.

Proof.

Since the Xi,Yisubscript𝑋𝑖subscript𝑌𝑖X_{i},Y_{i} are commuting positive definite matrices and Y𝑌Y is positive definite, f​(X|Y)𝑓conditional𝑋𝑌f(X|Y) is similar to the matrix

P=Y−1/2​(∑i=1nYi1/2​Xi​Yi1/2)​Y−1/2.𝑃superscript𝑌12superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑌𝑖12subscript𝑋𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑌𝑖12superscript𝑌12P=Y^{-1/2}\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n}Y_{i}^{1/2}X_{i}Y_{i}^{1/2}\right)Y^{-1/2}.

By assumption, Xi⪯b​Iprecedes-or-equalssubscript𝑋𝑖𝑏𝐼X_{i}\preceq bI. Therefore,

Yi1/2​Xi​Yi1/2⪯Yi1/2​b​I​Yi1/2=b​Yi.precedes-or-equalssuperscriptsubscript𝑌𝑖12subscript𝑋𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑌𝑖12superscriptsubscript𝑌𝑖12𝑏𝐼superscriptsubscript𝑌𝑖12𝑏subscript𝑌𝑖Y_{i}^{1/2}X_{i}Y_{i}^{1/2}\preceq Y_{i}^{1/2}bIY_{i}^{1/2}=bY_{i}.

Hence, we have

∑i=1nYi1/2​Xi​Yi1/2⪯b​Y.precedes-or-equalssuperscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑌𝑖12subscript𝑋𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑌𝑖12𝑏𝑌\sum_{i=1}^{n}Y_{i}^{1/2}X_{i}Y_{i}^{1/2}\preceq bY.

Thus,

P⪯b​Y−1/2​Y​Y−1/2=b​I.precedes-or-equals𝑃𝑏superscript𝑌12𝑌superscript𝑌12𝑏𝐼P\preceq bY^{-1/2}YY^{-1/2}=bI.

An analogous argument shows that P⪰a​Isucceeds-or-equals𝑃𝑎𝐼P\succeq aI. By basic properties of matrix similarity, we therefore find a​I⪯f​(X|Y)⪯b​Iprecedes-or-equals𝑎𝐼𝑓conditional𝑋𝑌precedes-or-equals𝑏𝐼aI\preceq f(X|Y)\preceq bI. ∎

We can use this matrix-weighted mean to define a normalized, matrix-weighted version of the mean absolute deviation.

Definition 3.

The normalized matrix-weighted discrepancy of {X1,…​Xn}subscript𝑋1…subscript𝑋𝑛\{X_{1},\dots X_{n}\} with respect to {Y1,…​Yn}subscript𝑌1…subscript𝑌𝑛\{Y_{1},\dots Y_{n}\} is given by

M​(X1,…​Xn|Y1,…,Yn)=∑i=1n∥Y−1​f​(X|Y)−1​(Xi−f​(X|Y))​Yi∥𝑀subscript𝑋1conditional…subscript𝑋𝑛subscript𝑌1…subscript𝑌𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛delimited-∥∥superscript𝑌1𝑓superscriptconditional𝑋𝑌1subscript𝑋𝑖𝑓conditional𝑋𝑌subscript𝑌𝑖M(X_{1},\dots X_{n}|Y_{1},\dots,Y_{n})=\sum_{i=1}^{n}\left\lVert Y^{-1}f(X|Y)^{-1}(X_{i}-f(X|Y))Y_{i}\right\rVert

where ∥⋅∥delimited-∥∥⋅\left\lVert\cdot\right\rVert is the operator norm.

Note that when d=1𝑑1d=1, M​(X|Y)=D​(X)/|𝔼[X]|𝑀conditional𝑋𝑌𝐷𝑋𝔼𝑋M(X|Y)=D(X)/|\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}[X]|, where D​(X)𝐷𝑋D(X) is as in Definition 1 and X𝑋X takes on values X1,…​Xn>0subscript𝑋1…subscript𝑋𝑛0X_{1},\dots X_{n}>0 with probabilities Y1,…​Yn>0subscript𝑌1…subscript𝑌𝑛0Y_{1},\dots Y_{n}>0.

We will prove an analog of Theorem 5 for this normalized matrix-weighted discrepancy.

Theorem 6.

Let X1,…​Xnsubscript𝑋1…subscript𝑋𝑛X_{1},\dots X_{n} be symmetric matrices in ℝd×dsuperscriptℝ𝑑𝑑\mathbb{R}^{d\times d} satisfying a​I⪯Xi⪯b​Iprecedes-or-equals𝑎𝐼subscript𝑋𝑖precedes-or-equals𝑏𝐼aI\preceq X_{i}\preceq bI for all i𝑖i, and suppose Y1,…​Ynsubscript𝑌1…subscript𝑌𝑛Y_{1},\dots Y_{n} are symmetric, positive-definite matrices in ℝd×dsuperscriptℝ𝑑𝑑\mathbb{R}^{d\times d}. Then

M​(X1,…​Xn|Y1,…​Yn)≤2​(b−a)b.𝑀subscript𝑋1conditional…subscript𝑋𝑛subscript𝑌1…subscript𝑌𝑛2𝑏𝑎𝑏M(X_{1},\dots X_{n}|Y_{1},\dots Y_{n})\leq\dfrac{2(b-a)}{b}.

To prove this, we will require a straightforward lemma regarding eigenvalues of symmetric positive definite matrices.

Lemma 14.

Let P1,P2subscript𝑃1subscript𝑃2P_{1},P_{2} be symmetric positive definite matrices and let P=P1+P2𝑃subscript𝑃1subscript𝑃2P=P_{1}+P_{2}. Then

∥P1​P−1∥≤1.delimited-∥∥subscript𝑃1superscript𝑃11\left\lVert P_{1}P^{-1}\right\rVert\leq 1.
Proof.

By basic properties of the Loewner ordering,

P1⪯P⟹P−1/2​P1​P−1/2⪯P−1/2​P​P−1/2=I.precedes-or-equalssubscript𝑃1𝑃superscript𝑃12subscript𝑃1superscript𝑃12precedes-or-equalssuperscript𝑃12𝑃superscript𝑃12𝐼P_{1}\preceq P\implies P^{-1/2}P_{1}P^{-1/2}\preceq P^{-1/2}PP^{-1/2}=I.

Since P1​P−1subscript𝑃1superscript𝑃1P_{1}P^{-1} is similar to P−1/2​P1​P−1/2superscript𝑃12subscript𝑃1superscript𝑃12P^{-1/2}P_{1}P^{-1/2}, we have

∥P1​P−1∥=∥P−1/2​P1​P−1/2∥≤1.delimited-∥∥subscript𝑃1superscript𝑃1delimited-∥∥superscript𝑃12subscript𝑃1superscript𝑃121\left\lVert P_{1}P^{-1}\right\rVert=\left\lVert P^{-1/2}P_{1}P^{-1/2}\right\rVert\leq 1.

∎

We can now prove Theorem 6.

We can now prove Lemma 5.

Proof.

For brevity, we will let Qisubscript𝑄𝑖Q_{i} denote Qi​(α,γ,Θ)subscript𝑄𝑖𝛼𝛾ΘQ_{i}(\alpha,\gamma,\Theta). Here we used Lemma 9, which in particular shows that since γ<(L+α)−1𝛾superscript𝐿𝛼1\gamma<(L+\alpha)^{-1}, all the Qisubscript𝑄𝑖Q_{i} are positive definite. Moreover, Lemma 9 shows that Qi,Aisubscript𝑄𝑖subscript𝐴𝑖Q_{i},A_{i} share the same eigenvectors, and therefore commute with one another. Hence, the Qisubscript𝑄𝑖Q_{i} commute with the Yisubscript𝑌𝑖Y_{i}. Moreover, by Assumption 1, the Yisubscript𝑌𝑖Y_{i} are positive definite symmetric matrices, and by Assumption 2, ∥ci∥≤Cdelimited-∥∥subscript𝑐𝑖𝐶\left\lVert c_{i}\right\rVert\leq C. Applying Theorem 6, we have

∥x∗​(α,γ,Θ)−x∗∥delimited-∥∥superscript𝑥𝛼𝛾Θsuperscript𝑥\displaystyle\left\lVert x^{*}(\alpha,\gamma,\Theta)-x^{*}\right\rVert ≤2​C​b−ab≤8​C​b−ab+aabsent2𝐶𝑏𝑎𝑏8𝐶𝑏𝑎𝑏𝑎\displaystyle\leq 2C\dfrac{b-a}{b}\leq 8C\dfrac{\sqrt{b}-\sqrt{a}}{\sqrt{b}+\sqrt{a}}

The last inequality holds from simple algebraic manipulation.

∎

Appendix D Additional Pareto Frontiers

D.1 Simulated MAML-style Pareto Frontiers

In order to plot Pareto frontiers for MAML-style methods (Θ=ΘKΘsubscriptΘ𝐾\Theta=\Theta_{K}) when γ>(K​L+α)−1𝛾superscript𝐾𝐿𝛼1\gamma>(KL+\alpha)^{-1}, we generate random symmetric matrices A∈ℝd×d𝐴superscriptℝ𝑑𝑑A\in\mathbb{R}^{d\times d} satisfying μ​I⪯A⪯L​Iprecedes-or-equals𝜇𝐼𝐴precedes-or-equals𝐿𝐼\mu I\preceq A\preceq LI. We then compute the associated matrix Q​(α,γ,ΘK)𝑄𝛼𝛾subscriptΘ𝐾Q(\alpha,\gamma,\Theta_{K}). Once we have these matrices, we can compute the condition number κ𝜅\kappa of Q​(α,γ,ΘK)​A𝑄𝛼𝛾subscriptΘ𝐾𝐴Q(\alpha,\gamma,\Theta_{K})A. We can then compute ρ,Δ𝜌Δ\rho,\Delta by substituting κ𝜅\kappa into Table 2 and Lemma 5.

To generate A𝐴A, we generate B𝐵B by sampling its entries independently from 𝒩​(0,1)𝒩01\mathcal{N}(0,1). We then set A=β1​B⊺​B+β2​I𝐴subscript𝛽1superscript𝐵⊺𝐵subscript𝛽2𝐼A=\beta_{1}B^{\intercal}B+\beta_{2}I, where β1,β2subscript𝛽1subscript𝛽2\beta_{1},\beta_{2} are the unique scalars such that

μ=λmin​(A)≤λmax​(A)=L.𝜇subscript𝜆𝐴subscript𝜆𝐴𝐿\mu=\lambda_{\min}(A)\leq\lambda_{\max}(A)=L.

We plot the resulting Pareto frontiers for varying L𝐿L and fixed μ𝜇\mu in Figure 7. We see that as L𝐿L increases with respect to μ𝜇\mu, the discrepancy between the MAML curves and the FedAvg curves grows. In particular, for small L/μ𝐿𝜇L/\mu, we see that the MAML curve recovers most of the FedAvg curve before diverging, while for large L/μ𝐿𝜇L/\mu, the two diverge almost immediately. Again, we see that when d=5𝑑5d=5, there is some noise in (ρ,Δ)𝜌Δ(\rho,\Delta), which seems to approach some limiting behavior for d=100𝑑100d=100.

We perform a similar experiment, but where we fix L=10𝐿10L=10 and vary ServerOpt over gradient descent with no momentum, with Nesterov momentum, and with heavy-ball momentum. The results are given in Figure 8. While the differences are not huge, we see that momentum helps convergence in all cases, FedAvg or MAML. Moreover, we see an interesting phenomenon where the type of momentum changes the concavity of the MAML Pareto frontier for d=100𝑑100d=100. As we add momentum, the region to the right of the MAML curve becomes more convex, becoming more rounded for heavy-ball momentum than for Nesterov momentum.

D.2 Proximal MAML-style Pareto Frontiers

In Figure 9 we plot the analog of the Pareto frontiers in Figure 3, but for MAML-style algorithms where Θ=ΘKΘsubscriptΘ𝐾\Theta=\Theta_{K}. We see a similar, though more subdued, version of the behavior in Figure 3. That is, adding a proximal term simply alters how much of the Pareto frontier is traversed; it does not change the fundamental shape. Note that here we only used γ𝛾\gamma satisfying γ<(K​L+α)−1𝛾superscript𝐾𝐿𝛼1\gamma<(KL+\alpha)^{-1}, as required by Theorem 3. In particular, the only restriction on the shape of the curve seems to be coming from the fact that larger α𝛼\alpha reduces the set of γ𝛾\gamma satisfying γ<(K​L+α)−1𝛾superscript𝐾𝐿𝛼1\gamma<(KL+\alpha)^{-1}.

To see the effects of α𝛼\alpha when γ≥(K​L+α)−1𝛾superscript𝐾𝐿𝛼1\gamma\geq(KL+\alpha)^{-1}, we use the same simulated approach as in Figure 5. We do this for varying α𝛼\alpha in Figure 10. We see that while increasing α𝛼\alpha shrinks the space of the Pareto curve of FedAvg, it does not seem to change the MAML curves by a meaningful amount.

Appendix E Experimental Setup

E.1 Datasets and Models

We use three datasets: the federated extended MNIST dataset (FEMNIST) (Caldas et al., 2018), CIFAR-100 (Krizhevsky and Hinton, 2009), and Shakespeare (Caldas et al., 2018). The first two are image datasets, and the third is a language dataset. All datasets are publicly available. We specifically use the versions available in TensorFlow Federated (Ingerman and Ostrowski, 2019), which gives a federated structure to all three. We keep the client partitioning when training, and create a test dataset by taking a union over all test client datasets. Statistics on the number of clients and examples in each dataset are given in Table 3.

FEMNIST

The FEMNIST dataset consists of images hand-written alphanumeric characters. There are 62 total alphanumeric characters represented in the dataset. The images are partitioned among clients according to their author. The dataset has natural heterogeneity stemming from the writing style of each person. We train a convolutional network on the dataset (the same one used by Reddi et al. (2020)). The network has two convolutional layers. Each convolutional layer uses 3×3333\times 3 kernels, max pooling, and then dropout with probability p=0.25𝑝0.25p=0.25. The model has a final dense softmax output layer.

CIFAR-100

The CIFAR-100 dataset is a computer vision dataset consisting of 32×32×33232332\times 32\times 3 images with 100 possible labels. While this dataset does not have a natural partition among clients, a federated version was created by Reddi et al. (2020) using hierarchical latent Dirichlet allocation to enforce moderate amounts of heterogeneity among clients. We train a ResNet-18 on this dataset, where we replace all batch normalization layers with group normalization layers (Wu and He, 2018). The use of group norm over batch norm in federated learning was first advocated by Hsieh et al. (2019).

We perform small amounts of data augmentation and preprocessing, as is standard with CIFAR-100. We first perform a random crop to shape (24,24,3)24243(24,24,3), followed by a random horizontal flip. We then normalize the pixel values according to their mean and standard deviation. Thus, given an image x𝑥x, we compute (x−μ)/σ𝑥𝜇𝜎(x-\mu)/\sigma where μ𝜇\mu is the average of the pixel values in x𝑥x, and σ𝜎\sigma is the standard deviation.

Shakespeare

The Shakespeare dataset is derived from the benchmark designed by Caldas et al. (2018). The dataset corpus is the collected works of William Shakespeare, and the clients correspond to roles in Shakespeare’s plays with at least two lines of dialogue. To eliminate confusion, character here will refer to alphanumeric and other such symbols, while we will use client to denote the various roles in plays. We split each client’s lines into sequences of 80 characters, padding if necessary. We use a vocabulary size of 90: 86 characters contained in Shakespeare’s work, beginning and end of line tokens, padding tokens, and out-of-vocabulary tokens. We perform next-character prediction on the clients’ dialogue using an RNN. The RNN takes as input a sequence of 80 characters, embeds it into a learned 8-dimensional space, and passes the embedding through 2 LSTM layers, each with 256 units. Finally, we use a softmax output layer with 80 units, where we try to predict a sequence of 80 characters formed by shifting the input sequence over by one. Therefore, our output dimension is 80×90809080\times 90. We compute loss using cross-entropy loss.

E.2 Implementation and Hyperparameters

We implement LocalUpdate in TensorFlow Federated (Ingerman and Ostrowski, 2019). We use LocalUpdate with Θ=Θ1:KΘsubscriptΘ:1𝐾\Theta=\Theta_{1:K} and client learning rate γ𝛾\gamma. In all experiments, ServerOpt is gradient descent with server learning rate η𝜂\eta, with either no momentum, Nesterov momentum, or heavy-ball momentum. We sample M=10𝑀10M=10 clients per round. We sample without replacement within a given round, and with replacement across rounds. In order to derive fair comparisons between different hyperparameter settings, we use a random seed to fix which clients are sampled at each round. We use a batch size of B=20𝐵20B=20 for FEMNIST and CIFAR-100, and B=4𝐵4B=4 for Shakespeare.

E.3 Details of Figure 6

For posterity’s sake, we re-plot Figure 6 in Figure 11. To generate these plots, we perform two distinct experiments. In the first experiment (Figures 6 and 11, left), we fix α=0𝛼0\alpha=0 and vary ServerOpt. Specifically, we let ServerOpt be gradient descent with no momentum (gradient), gradient descent with Nesterov momentum (nesterov), and gradient descent with heavy-ball momentum (momentum). When ServerOpt uses Nesterov or heavy-ball momentum, we use a momentum parameter of β=0.9𝛽0.9\beta=0.9. In the second experiment (Figures 6 and 11, right), we fix ServerOpt to be gradient descent with no momentum, and vary the proximal strength α𝛼\alpha. In both cases, we fix Θ=Θ1:50ΘsubscriptΘ:150\Theta=\Theta_{1:50}, and tune γ,η𝛾𝜂\gamma,\eta over the range

γ,η∈{10−3,10−2.5,…,100.5,10}.𝛾𝜂superscript103superscript102.5…superscript100.510\gamma,\eta\in\{10^{-3},10^{-2.5},\dots,10^{0.5},10\}.

We select the values of γ,η𝛾𝜂\gamma,\eta attaining the best average test accuracy over the last 100 rounds.

Appendix F Additional Experiments

We wish to showcase the convergence-accuracy trade-off discussed in Section 4 in non-convex settings. We train LocalUpdate with α=0𝛼0\alpha=0, Θ=Θ1:10ΘsubscriptΘ:110\Theta=\Theta_{1:10}, and let ServerOpt be gradient descent with learning rate η𝜂\eta. First, we fix η=0.01𝜂0.01\eta=0.01 and vary γ𝛾\gamma over

γ∈{0,10−3,10−2,10−1,1,10}.𝛾0superscript103superscript102superscript101110\gamma\in\{0,10^{-3},10^{-2},10^{-1},1,10\}.

We plot the training loss over time on all three datasets in Figure 12, omitting results that diverge due to γ𝛾\gamma being too large.

We see that on all three tasks, especially CIFAR-100, the choice of client learning rate can impact not just the speed of convergence, but what point the algorithm converges to. In general, we see very similar behavior to that described in Sections 4 and 5, despite the non-convex loss functions involved in all three tasks. For both FEMNIST and CIFAR-100, smaller client learning rates eventually reach lower training losses than higher learning rates. This is particularly evident in the results for CIFAR-100. While γ=10−2𝛾superscript102\gamma=10^{-2} initially performs better than all other methods, it is eventually surpassed by γ=10−3𝛾superscript103\gamma=10^{-3}, and γ=0𝛾0\gamma=0 ends up obtaining a comparable accuracy. This reflects the idea presented in Section 5 that hyperparameters should be chosen according to the desired convergence-accuracy trade-off. In communication-limited settings, we should use larger γ𝛾\gamma (or K𝐾K), while in cases where we can run many communication rounds, we should use smaller γ𝛾\gamma (or K𝐾K).

In short, we see clear evidence that the choice of client learning rate γ𝛾\gamma leads to a trade-off between convergence and accuracy. However, as shown in Lemmas 3 and 4, the condition number of the surrogate loss changes depending on parameters such as γ𝛾\gamma. To derive asymptotically optimal rates for strongly convex functions (such as the ones in Table 2), one must generally set the learning rate η𝜂\eta according to the condition number. Thus, we repeat the experiments in Figure 12, but where we tune the server learning rate η𝜂\eta instead of fixing it. This helps account for how the optimization dynamics can change as a function of the client learning rate γ𝛾\gamma. We vary the server learning rate η𝜂\eta over

η∈{10−3,10−2.5,…,10}𝜂superscript103superscript102.5…10\eta\in\{10^{-3},10^{-2.5},\dots,10\}

and select η𝜂\eta that leads to the smallest average training loss over the last 100 rounds. The result is given in Figure 13. Again, we see similar behavior, but see that when the server learning rate is tuned, larger client learning rates may do much better initially. This reflects the fact that in Table 2, the best convergence rates can only be obtained by setting parameters of ServerOpt correctly.

This points to another benefit of the Pareto frontiers proposed in Section 5. Many comparisons of different algorithms, especially empirical ones, can miss good hyperparameter settings. This is heightened by the fact that many FL and ML methods have hyperparameters for both client and server optimizers, comprehensive tuning extremely difficult. This may lead to unfair comparisons between methods. By contrast, the Pareto frontiers showcase convergence-accuracy trade-offs when the hyperparameters of ServerOpt are selected in an “optimal” way, helping derive fair comparisons between methods.
